page.title: 08FARMING IN FYLINGDALES
page.content: COWS. There are about six different breeds kept in Fylingdales. The two most common ones are the Friesians, which are kept for their milk and Charolais which are used for beef. The local Herefords are kept for breeding and beef. Each year the dairy Friesians have a calf. If it is a heifer it is kept for milking but if it is a bull calf it is sold to be fattened up for slaughtering. Simmentals and Limousins are foreign breeds which farmers use to increase the size of their animals. The Blue Grays are a cross. They are a hardy breed because they eat sparse grass and can live on either the hills or the moors.
